hawaiian_text: Lālau akula ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi a hele akula ā  hiki i waena ā loa‘a o Nāmakaokapāo‘o e kunu ana  i nā ‘au ‘uala āna ‘ehā, i luna o ke ahi. ‘Ike maila nā  keiki a pau loa, holo akula lākou ā kū maila ma kahi  lō‘ihi no ka maka‘u ia Puali‘i. ‘Ōlelo akula ‘o Puali‘i  iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “‘Ē\! Eia ke ko‘ilipi ma ku‘u  lima, he mea ‘o‘oki no kō po‘o i kēia lā, a moku kō po‘o, a laila, kālua me ka ‘uala, a ‘ai iho a‘u ma mua, a laila, noa.” ‘A‘ohe ho‘olohe mai ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kēia mau ‘ōlelo a Puali‘i, a laila,  ‘ōlelo hou ‘o Puali‘i, ‘o ka lua ia. Mākaukau ‘o  Puali‘i e ‘o‘oki ia Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke ko‘ilipi, i ia  wā i pule ai ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kāna pule make  no Puali‘i. Penei ua pule lā:  Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāo‘o, E hapupu‘u, e hāpāpa‘a mai nei,  E ‘ai paha, e waiho paha,  E waiho paha Nākukui‘aimakaokalani,  ‘O Kukui‘aimakaokalani kēlā,  ‘O ku‘u wahi aikāne kēia,  ‘O Nāmakaokai‘a ke ali‘i nui o Hawai‘i,  E he‘e lā, e he‘e ka hōhē wale,  ‘O kānaka nō me ka ihe,  ‘O ka ihe nō me ka pahu,  Make nō iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o.
llama-3.3-70B-Instruct_exl2_6.0bpw-maui_:
Puali'i was angry and grabbed an adze and went to where Nāmakaokapāo'o was kneeling, cooking four sweet potato vines on the fire. All the children saw and ran to a distance and stood watching Puali'i. Puali'i said to Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Here is the adze in my hand, it will cut off your head today and your head will be cooked with the sweet potato, and I will eat it first, and then it will be free." Nāmakaokapāo'o did not listen to Puali'i's words, and Puali'i spoke again, of the pit. Puali'i was ready to hit Nāmakaokapāo'o with the adze, at the time when Nāmakaokapāo'o was praying his death prayer for Puali'i. The prayer was like this: 
Love only the face of my pāo'o fish, 
Striking, opposing, 
Eating or leaving, 
Leaving perhaps Nākukui'aimakaokalani, 
That is Kukui'aimakaokalani, 
My pāo'o fish companion, 
Nāmakaokai'a is the great chief of Hawai'i, 
Move, move only the spear, 
The person with the spear, 
The spear with the dagger, 
Die because of Nāmakaokapāo'o.

• This passage marks a pivotal moment in the narrative where tensions between Puali'i and Nāmakaokapāo'o escalate: 
  – Puali'i's anger and decision to use the adze (ko'ilipi) against Nāmakaokapāo'o signifies a violent intent, characteristic of conflicts within the 'Ai Kapu era, where violence was sometimes used to resolve disputes or assert dominance.
  – The adze, a tool used for various tasks including woodworking and as a weapon, represents both utility and violence, symbolizing the duality of human nature in Hawaiian culture.
• The reaction of the children (keiki) running to a distance and watching Puali'i indicates fear and recognition of the severity of the situation, highlighting the impact of adult conflicts on the community, especially the younger members.
• Nāmakaokapāo'o's indifference to Puali'i's threats and his engagement in a death prayer (pule make) for Puali'i suggest a spiritual or mystical dimension to their conflict:
  – The content of Nāmakaokapāo'o's prayer provides insight into his character, invoking the imagery of the pāo'o fish and referencing figures like Nākukui'aimakaokalani and Nāmakaokai'a, which may symbolize ancestral or divine connections.
  – The mention of Kukui'aimakaokalani as a companion and the reference to Nāmakaokai'a as a great chief of Hawai'i indicate a complex network of relationships and alliances, possibly alluding to real or mythical historical figures.
  – The use of natural imagery and the invocation of powerful beings or concepts (like the pāo'o fish, the great chief of Hawai'i, and the action of spears and daggers) in the prayer may serve to underscore the spiritual or transcendental aspects of the conflict, suggesting that the outcomes are not solely determined by human actions but also by divine or cosmic forces.
• The allegorical interpretation of this passage might involve the struggle between old and new, tradition and change, symbolized by the characters of Puali'i and Nāmakaokapāo'o:
  – Puali'i, with his adherence to possibly outdated customs or his resistance to change, might represent the old order or the 'Ai Kapu system, which was characterized by strict rules and hierarchies.
  – Nāmakaokapāo'o, with his unique strength, destructive behavior, and spiritual practices, could symbolize the forces of change or the future, potentially embodying characteristics that would become more prevalent in a post-'Ai Kapu society.
• The cultural practice of prayer and invocation of ancestral or divine beings for assistance in conflict resolution or for harming others is reminiscent of practices within the 'Ai Kapu era, where spiritual power and connection to the gods were crucial for legitimacy and success:
  – The specific prayer by Nāmakaokapāo'o, with its references to love, striking, eating or leaving, and the naming of specific beings or concepts, demonstrates a sophisticated spiritual system where individuals could invoke divine power for personal purposes, including harm or protection.
  – This passage also highlights the importance of name etymology and the potential hidden meanings within names like Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o (the eyes of the pāo'o fish), Nā-kukui-'ai-maka-o-kalani (possibly related to light, food, and the heavens), and Nā-maka-o-kai'a (eyes of the fish of the sea or chief), which may hold significant cultural, spiritual, or historical value.
raw_response:
<translation>
Puali'i was angry and grabbed an adze and went to where Nāmakaokapāo'o was kneeling, cooking four sweet potato vines on the fire. All the children saw and ran to a distance and stood watching Puali'i. Puali'i said to Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Here is the adze in my hand, it will cut off your head today and your head will be cooked with the sweet potato, and I will eat it first, and then it will be free." Nāmakaokapāo'o did not listen to Puali'i's words, and Puali'i spoke again, of the pit. Puali'i was ready to hit Nāmakaokapāo'o with the adze, at the time when Nāmakaokapāo'o was praying his death prayer for Puali'i. The prayer was like this: 
Love only the face of my pāo'o fish, 
Striking, opposing, 
Eating or leaving, 
Leaving perhaps Nākukui'aimakaokalani, 
That is Kukui'aimakaokalani, 
My pāo'o fish companion, 
Nāmakaokai'a is the great chief of Hawai'i, 
Move, move only the spear, 
The person with the spear, 
The spear with the dagger, 
Die because of Nāmakaokapāo'o.
</translation>

<commentary>
• This passage marks a pivotal moment in the narrative where tensions between Puali'i and Nāmakaokapāo'o escalate: 
  – Puali'i's anger and decision to use the adze (ko'ilipi) against Nāmakaokapāo'o signifies a violent intent, characteristic of conflicts within the 'Ai Kapu era, where violence was sometimes used to resolve disputes or assert dominance.
  – The adze, a tool used for various tasks including woodworking and as a weapon, represents both utility and violence, symbolizing the duality of human nature in Hawaiian culture.
• The reaction of the children (keiki) running to a distance and watching Puali'i indicates fear and recognition of the severity of the situation, highlighting the impact of adult conflicts on the community, especially the younger members.
• Nāmakaokapāo'o's indifference to Puali'i's threats and his engagement in a death prayer (pule make) for Puali'i suggest a spiritual or mystical dimension to their conflict:
  – The content of Nāmakaokapāo'o's prayer provides insight into his character, invoking the imagery of the pāo'o fish and referencing figures like Nākukui'aimakaokalani and Nāmakaokai'a, which may symbolize ancestral or divine connections.
  – The mention of Kukui'aimakaokalani as a companion and the reference to Nāmakaokai'a as a great chief of Hawai'i indicate a complex network of relationships and alliances, possibly alluding to real or mythical historical figures.
  – The use of natural imagery and the invocation of powerful beings or concepts (like the pāo'o fish, the great chief of Hawai'i, and the action of spears and daggers) in the prayer may serve to underscore the spiritual or transcendental aspects of the conflict, suggesting that the outcomes are not solely determined by human actions but also by divine or cosmic forces.
• The allegorical interpretation of this passage might involve the struggle between old and new, tradition and change, symbolized by the characters of Puali'i and Nāmakaokapāo'o:
  – Puali'i, with his adherence to possibly outdated customs or his resistance to change, might represent the old order or the 'Ai Kapu system, which was characterized by strict rules and hierarchies.
  – Nāmakaokapāo'o, with his unique strength, destructive behavior, and spiritual practices, could symbolize the forces of change or the future, potentially embodying characteristics that would become more prevalent in a post-'Ai Kapu society.
• The cultural practice of prayer and invocation of ancestral or divine beings for assistance in conflict resolution or for harming others is reminiscent of practices within the 'Ai Kapu era, where spiritual power and connection to the gods were crucial for legitimacy and success:
  – The specific prayer by Nāmakaokapāo'o, with its references to love, striking, eating or leaving, and the naming of specific beings or concepts, demonstrates a sophisticated spiritual system where individuals could invoke divine power for personal purposes, including harm or protection.
  – This passage also highlights the importance of name etymology and the potential hidden meanings within names like Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o (the eyes of the pāo'o fish), Nā-kukui-'ai-maka-o-kalani (possibly related to light, food, and the heavens), and Nā-maka-o-kai'a (eyes of the fish of the sea or chief), which may hold significant cultural, spiritual, or historical value.</commentary>
reference_translation: Puali‘i grabbed and adze and went out to the  middle of the patches and found Nāmakaokapāo‘o  cooking four sweet potato vines on the fire. All the  children saw this and ran off and stood a long  distance away since they were so afraid of Puali‘i.  Puali‘i said to Nāmakaokapāo‘o, “Hey\! I got an  adze in my hand to cut off your head today. When  I cut your head off, I’ll cook it in the imu with  sweet potatoes and I’ll eat first, and then, it’ll be  free for others.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o paid no  attention to what Puali‘i said and Puali‘i said it  again. Puali‘i got ready to strike Nāmakaokapāo‘o  with the adze, and at that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o  prayed a prayer of death of Puali‘i. This is what he  prayed:  How sad for the eyes of my precious pāo‘o fish Heaped up and burnt Should I eat it or leave it aside?  Maybe I should leave Nākukui‘aimakaokalani  alone  It is Kukui‘aimakaokalani afterall  My good friend.  Nāmakaokai‘a is the great chief of Hawai‘i Escaping, the coward escapes  The men with spears  Spears and drums  Killed by Nāmakaokapāo‘o
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 7:**• Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o was in the process of cooking 4  sweet potato vines after destroying the sweet potato  garden. It could be that the 4 vines represent the 4  primary gods of the Hawaiian people: Kāne, Kanaloa,  Kū, and Lono. Sweet potato was one of the most  important food crops that sustained the people (represented in this story by sweet potato and ulua  fish), along with taro (another representation of  humans), and this symbolically could represent the  only esoteric epistemology and lifestyle the Hawaiian  people ever knew in the ‘Ai Kapu era. Cooking the  vine and leaves renders the vegetable edible, while  also killing it, a type of ritual canibalism.  • The words of the prayer offered in chant form  (prosidy) are a type of lament by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o  for Pua-li‘i (i.e. pitying him) and a prediction that Pua li‘i would die a gruesome death despite the fact that  Pua-li‘i was the one about to attack Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o with an adze. The prayer essentially says that  enlightenment would consume the eater of the flesh  of men and that the customs of war and hula (i.e.  ʻpahu’) would retreat like cowards, having been killed  off by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o. This is likely a reference  to Christian ʻenlightenment’ replacing the ‘Ai Kapu  across the Hawaiian Islands.
